pkgmetadata.longdescription: # distribution-algebraA python package that implements an easy-to-use interface for randomvariables, statistical distributions, and their algebra.This Python package is brought to you by [Vaibhav Karve](https://vaibhavkarve.github.io).`distribution-algebra` recognizes Normal, Lognormal, Beta and Poissondistributions. The package implements an interface to easily constructuser-defined Univariate distributions as well Vectorized distributions.Additional features include:- A `plot` function for probability density/mass function plotting.- A `draw` function for drawing random samples of specified size from a given distribution.- Addition and multiplication operations defined directly on distributions: - For example, the sum of two Normal (Poisson) distributions is Normal (Poisson). - The product of two Lognormal distributions is Lognormal. - The sum of two arbitrary univariate distributions is expressed as a Vectorized distribution.![Example plot](https://github.com/vaibhavkarve/distribution-algebra/raw/main/docs/example_plot_univariate.png)This package is written in Python v3.10, and is publicly availableunder the [GNU-GPL-v3.0license](https://github.com/vaibhavkarve/normal-form/blob/main/LICENSE).# Installation and usageTo get started on using this package,1. Install Python 3.10 or higher.2. `python3.10 -m pip install distribution-algebra`3. Use it in a python script (or interactive REPL) ```python from distribution_algebra import Beta, Lognormal, Normal, Poisson x: Normal = Normal(mean=1.0, var=9.0)y: Normal = Normal(mean=1.0, var=16.0)assert x + y == Normal(mean=2.0, var=25.0) ```
